Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to
the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the

• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Repeat violations.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint, pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints
Description (2) The following restraints are strictly prohibited:
(e)Restraining youth in a prone position or any restraint that
restricts the youth’s airway.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was placed into a prone position for approximately 21
minutes by staff.
Investigation Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 was interviewed face to
face at the facility on 7/27/23 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. They reported being aware of the allegations because the
facility called in the report to DHHS. The facility is conducting their
own investigation and have suspended Staff 1, Staff 2, and
Supervisor 2 who were involved in the restraint and Supervisor 3
and Nurse Manager who were observing the restraint of Youth A.
They also reported being informed of the incident right after it
occurred, and it was then they suspended the staff mentioned
above. Supervisor 3 and Nurse Manager were suspended
because they observed the inappropriate restrain and failed to
stop it or report it. They also reported Nurse Manager had
resigned her position right after being questioned about the
restraint.
Youth A was observed face to face at the facility on 7/27/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He showed bruising on his
upper left arm and wrist area. He reported feeling “alright” at this
time and that he was upset prior to the restraint because his
mother left him.
DHHS Case Manager was interviewed via phone on 7/28/23.
She reported having a face-to-face contact with Youth A earlier in
the day and had no concerns at this time. She also reported
having no concerns with the services being provided by the
facility. She reported Youth A is struggling to make progress for
his “sexual reactiveness” and will likely move to an adult mental
health facility in the future.
2

Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/2/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
walking into the hallway and once observing the restraint, telling
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Supervisor 2 to release their hold on Youth A.
She did this because they were holding him in a prone position
which is not allowed. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Supervisor 2 all released
Youth A in seconds after she told them to release. Nurse Manager
was present, and Supervisor 3 was pacing the hallway when
Supervisor 1 entered the hallway. She reported saying to Staff 1,
Staff 2, and Supervisor 2 who were holding Youth A, “what the hell
are you doing, turn him over”. She was unsure who told her the
staff had to put him into this hold because Youth A was trying to
stab staff and “they had no choice”. Once released, Youth A sat
up and leaned against the wall while crying. Supervisor 1 did not
see any pencil nor any injuries on Youth A. Staff 1, Staff 2, and
Supervisor 2 all told her Youth A was in the restraint for 20 to 21
minutes. Immediately after administrating the medication to Youth
A and leaving the area, Supervisor 1 called “Risk Management”
and the Chief Operating Officer about the inappropriate restraint.
Supervisor 1 also reported all staff have yearly refresher training
on restraints and they are told to never use the prone position.
Complainant was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/2/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
having no firsthand information about the incident. She is in
charge of Recipient Rights at the facility and was informed of the
restraint by Administrator 2 who informed her he received the
information from Supervisor 1 the day of the incident. She
reviewed the video recording of the incident and identified Staff 1
holding Youth A’s left arm and side, while Staff 2 held Youth A’s
right arm and side. Supervisor 2 held Youth A's legs during the
prone restraint with Nurse Manager holding Youth A’s legs for a
couple of minutes. Supervisor 3 called for medication and
Clinician came to the scene and appeared to speak to Youth A for
about 10 minutes before leaving. Complainant also reported the
incident began when Youth A pushed himself off the wall and
attempted to kick Staff 1. Staff 1 grabbed Youth A’s leg and Youth
A fell to the ground in a prone position. When Youth A was on the
floor, Staff 1, Staff 2, and Supervisor 2 began the restraint.
Complainant reported when interviewing Staff 1, Staff 2,
Supervisor 2, Nurse Manager, and Supervisor 3, they all admitted
to knowing Youth A should not have been in a prone position for
the restraint. All of these staff are trained in appropriate restraints.
Staff 1 was the supervisor on the floor and “made the call” for the
restraint to begin. Complainant also reported it was mentioned
that Staff 2 said during the restraint, “Youth A should not be on his
3

stomach”. She was unable to recall which staff reported this
information. Staff 1 was resistant to moving Youth A from the
prone position because he believed it was more dangerous to
move him given his aggression earlier. Complainant also reported
Youth A appeared calm throughout most of the restraint.
Administrator 2 was interviewed again face to face at the
facility on 8/2/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He
reported being informed of the inappropriate restraint on the day it
occurred (7/25/23) and after talking with Supervisor 1 and
watching the video recording, contacting Complainant and
Administrator 2. Both Administrator 2 and Complainant began
interviews with staff and Youth A on 7/26/23 and having
Complainant report the incident to DHHS on the morning of
7/27/23.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/2/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported being in the role
of a residential staff at the time of the incident and that he will
work as a supervisor at times during other shifts. He reported
noticing Youth A was having some difficulty early in the morning
and at one point had barricaded himself in the bathroom. After
being asked to assist with Youth A’s hygiene, Staff 1 went to
assist and found Youth A with a pencil making stabbing motions
towards Staff 2. Staff 1 circled behind Youth A and was able to
grab the pencil from him from behind. Youth A then grabbed an
eraser, throwing it at Staff 1 before punching Staff 1 a couple of
times. As Staff 1 turned and walked away from Youth A, Youth A
attempted to kick Staff 1. Staff 1 was able to grab Youth A’s leg
and when letting go, Youth A fell to the ground in a prone position.
Staff 1 reported Youth A was laying on the ground making hissing
sounds noting he “makes this type of noise when being
aggressive” and no one was touching him. Staff 1 believed Youth
A was getting ready to become more aggressive as his “hissing
was increasing, and this generally means he is becoming more
rageful”. Staff 1 secured Youth A’s left arm while Staff 2 secured
Youth A’s right arm. After Youth A kicked Staff 1 with his knee in
Staff 1’s side, Supervisor 2 became involved and held Youth A’s
legs. Staff 1 reported beginning the restraint because he believed
Youth A was going to get up and “go after someone else”. Youth A
kept trying to get up while Staff 1 was trying to keep him calm.
Staff 1 also reported Youth A was “thrashing around and trying to
pull his arms free”. Every time, Staff 1 attempted to let go of Youth
A, Youth A would keep fighting and saying he wanted to hurt staff.
Staff 1 also believed Youth A had a belief that if he got hurt his
father would come to the facility and take him home and Youth A
4

will act out aggressively to “release the fire inside of him”. Staff 1
based these beliefs on past statements Youth A has made to staff.
Staff 1 also reported they were unable to move Youth A into
another position because he would kick staff, and someone would
get hurt. Staff 1 reported there was no safe way to release Youth
A because he would have been a danger to himself and others.
Staff 1 had this belief because Youth A was attempting to bite staff
during the restraint. Staff 1 reported when Supervisor 1 came on
the scene, she told staff she could not give medication to a youth
in the prone position. When Supervisor 1 came on the scene,
Youth A stopped struggling and was allowed to sit up. Once up,
Staff 1 also reported Youth A went to the backdoor and kicked it
open. Staff 1 doesn’t’ recall anyone saying Youth A should be let
up because they were so focused on keeping Youth A in control.
Staff 1 reported the facility used to use the prone position and they
are now trained not to use the prone position but sometimes, “the
youth just get into that position”. Staff 1 believed they needed
more help and sometimes as in this situation, there just isn’t
enough help.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/2/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported prior to the
restraint, Youth A got into an argument with a peer twice before
barricading himself in the bathroom. Once leaving the bathroom
he started kicking doors while yelling and screaming. Staff 2
stayed in the hallway with him until Supervisor 3 came into the
hall. Youth A then pulled out a pencil and started punching Staff 1
in the chest. Youth A also kicked at Staff 1’s legs before he began
to act like he was stabbing someone. Staff 2 gave the same report
about the beginning of the restraint when Youth A pushed off the
wall and attempted to kick Staff 1. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 said
“let’s restrain Youth A” while Youth A was in the prone position on
the floor. Staff 2 believed Youth A was in “attack mode” because
he was struggling. Staff 1 started the restraint and Staff 2 joined
by grabbing Youth A’s right arm. Staff 2 asked Staff 1 “are you
sure we are doing this” and was told yes because the nurse is not
there yet and there is not a lot of staff present. Youth A is also on
suicide precautions which requires more supervision. Staff 2
reported he was questioning the quickness of the restraint
because “staff should never put a youth in a prone restraint”. Staff
2 also reported Supervisor 1 came on the scene and told staff
Youth A cannot be in a prone position, so Staff 2 helped get Youth
A up to a sitting position. Youth A was still upset when released
but he sat on the floor leaning against the wall. Staff 2 shared the
belief the facility doesn’t teach staff never to put a youth in the
5

prone position. He reported staff are taught to not move a youth
during a restraint because of safety issues.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/2/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She gave a similar
report about the beginning of the incident as Staff 2. She reported
Youth A wanted a break from school before leaving and returning
to the classroom. Youth A left the classroom again and barricaded
himself in the bathroom. After Youth A came out of the bathroom,
he began to walk up the hallway with Staff 1, Staff 2, and
Supervisor 2. Youth A had his fists clinched before he “took a
swing at Staff 1. She overheard Staff 1 ask Youth A what was in
his hand and when looking she noticed the pencil. Youth A
became aggressive by swing and kicking at staff and when trying
to kick at Staff 1, Staff 1 grabbed his foot and Youth A ended up
on the floor in a prone position. Supervisor 2 recalled Staff 1
asked Staff 2 to grab Youth A’s right arm and Staff 2 responded
with “are we really going to do this”. Staff 1 asked Supervisor 2 to
put hands on Youth A’s legs and she was able to “cuff” his legs,
so his legs were not touching the ground. Supervisor 2 reported
after Staff 1 called for the restraint, Youth A began to attempt to
bite staff. Prior to her grabbing Youth A’s legs and prior to the
restraint, while Youth A was laying in the prone position, he was
not kicking but once the restraint began Youth A started “horse
kicking”. Supervisor 3 left the area at the beginning of the restraint
to call for a nurse. Supervisor 2 acknowledged staff are not to use
a prone position in a restraint because this rule changed a few
years ago but she was unsure if they are trained not to use a
prone restraint. She believed Youth A should have been released
even if he was still a danger to himself or others but never said
anything about it. Supervisor 2 reported until Supervisor 1 said
something none of the other staff said anything about their action
being an inappropriate restraint. Even when Clinician came on the
scene and spoke with Youth A, she said nothing about the
restraint position. Supervisor 2 also reported after the restraint,
Staff 1 told her he was “sorry to have called the restraint”.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/2/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being
present during the incident involving the prone restraint of Youth
A. She was in the office area with Supervisor 2 when Staff 2
brought Youth A to the office indicating Youth A needed a break.
Youth A kept wandering off even though Supervisor 2 provided
redirection. Supervisor 2 took Youth A back to the classroom while
Supervisor 3 remained at the desk. When looking down the hall
she noticed Staff 2 was alone with Youth A, so she went down the
6

hall to provide support if needed. Youth A was kicking doors and
both Staff 2 and Supervisor 3 attempted to help him calm down.
As Supervisor 3 was moving a desk out of the way, Youth A
approached her and “tried to push through the door” behind her.
She noticed a pencil in his hand and told him to give it up, but he
just walked down the hall. Down the hall, Supervisor 2 and Staff 1
came on scene and Youth A tried to stab Staff 1 with the pencil.
Staff 1 grabbed the pencil and Youth A began to kick doors again
before moving towards Staff 1. Staff 1 blocked a kick from Youth A
and Youth A fell to the floor. Supervisor 3 reported not observing
the whole restraint but once Youth A was on the floor, she got on
the floor with him. Staff 1 informed her she needed to call the
nurse, so she left to call the nurse. Nurse Manager called
Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 1 arrived with the injection form of
medication. While waiting, Supervisor 3 observed the restraint and
Staff 1 informed everyone that Youth A keeps fighting and will not
calm down. When Supervisor 1 came on scene, she talked to
Youth A, and he calmed down. Supervisor 3 believes Youth A
calmed down because Supervisor 1 was not part of the restraint.
Supervisor 3 reported Supervisor 1 informed staff she will not give
the injection because the prone position was inappropriate, and
Supervisor 3 was unaware that a prone position was
inappropriate. She is unaware if prone position is taught in training
and not all staff are aware that you can’t use a prone position. She
was unsure why she didn’t stop the restraint and she reported she
would not have started the restraint to begin with.
Clinician was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/2/23
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported going to “get
a kid” for a therapy session when she observed Youth A in a
restraint in the hallway. She walked over to him to see if she
would be able to speak to him. She also reported Youth A was
face down, while yelling and screaming. Staff 1 had his left arm,
Staff 2 had his right arm, and Supervisor 2 was “on his feet”. She
reported her attempt to speak with Youth A did not calm him
down, but she knows he calmed down after the restraint. She
believes all of the staff including herself are trained in restraint
techniques and she learned later in a staff meeting that prone
restraints are inappropriate. She reported the thought that the
restraint was inappropriate didn’t cross her mind and stopping it
never occurred to her.
Trainer was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/2/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported being in the
position of training restraint techniques at the facility for the past 8
years. He also reported it is never appropriate to conduct a prone
7

position restraint and if you happened to end up in a prone
position staff are to turn the youth over as soon as possible or just
let go. None of the restraint trainers teach prone position restraints
and they are told to cross out the prone restraint and bear hug
from the training guides. Trainer believes it is not safe to hold a
youth in a prone position as opposed to not safe to move a youth
from a prone position. The reported restraint training is Non-
Violent Crisis Intervention (NVCI) which is part of Crisis
Prevention Intervention (COI).
Court Worker was interviewed face to face at the facility on
8/2/23 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported he has
a good rapport with Youth A and is able to help Youth A calm
down when he is having a bad day. He also reported staff’s
intervention is generally to talk to Youth A and help him calm
down. The normal consequences Youth A receives are reports
and write-ups rather than restraints. Youth A has informed Court
Worker that he feels safe in the program.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/2/23
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported thinking
about his brother and got caught up emotionally in some “stuff”.
He remembers grabbing a pencil and going after Staff 1. He
believes he deserves getting hurt because of what he did. He also
reported trying to kick Staff 1 and having Staff 1 turn him over
causing him to go to the ground. He was crying and struggling
because of the pressure on his arms and legs and it being hard to
get staff off of him. He reported asking them “nicely” to get off of
him and when he struggles in life, he makes mistakes. He also
reported being in a lot of pain from staff grabbing him and wanted
to “curl up in a ball”. He wanted staff to stop because of the pain
but “they just would not listen to me”. He stated, “I was on the floor
for an hour because I was on the struggle bus”. He reported
stopping his struggling once staff let go of him and just talking
about the restraint makes him nervous. He does not feel safe at
the facility because he feels like he will be attacked again by both
staff and other youth.
Nurse Manager was interviewed via phone on 8/16/23 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported receiving a call
that the impulse program (where Youth A is lodged) needed help.
When getting to the scene, she was informed they were in a
restraint and needed medication because their nurse was not
present today. Staff 1 had asked her to hold Youth A’s legs and
she did for approximately 2 minutes. After this she left and called
the doctor while going to get the medication. She also reported
8

Supervisor 1 told staff she would not administrator the medication
to Youth A because he was in a prone position which was
inappropriate. Nurse Manager spoke to Complainant right after
leaving the scene to inform her of the inappropriate restraint. She
reported staff are not supposed to place a youth in a prone
position and Youth A presented as not struggling. Youth A “looked
like he just wanted to get out of the hold” and she heard him say
several times “just let me go”. Nurse Manager also reported not
saying anything about the inappropriate restraint because “just
missed it”. She believed she was experiencing stress over the
number of hours she had been working because the facility is
normally short staffed.
Documents Reviewed:
Incident Report 159400208 Dated 7/25/23. This document is the
incident report for the prone restraint conducted on Youth A. This
document does not describe the type of restraint beyond staff
members securing Youth A’s right arm, left arm, and legs. It is
described that Youth A “continued struggling in an effort to free his
arms and legs and telling staff he was trying to stab and harm
them. This document also states Youth A said, “releasing the fire
within himself”. The report ends with “a nurse” giving him an
injection IM but nothing about the release or prone position.
Email from Auburn Hills Police Department dated 8/7/23. This
document states no crime was committed therefor the case is
being closed. It is also stated the video shows Youth A is
attempting to assault the workers and the workers are restraining
Youth A for his safety and the safety of others.
Residential Updated Service Plan for Youth A dated 6/4/2023.
This document outlines the services provided, treatment goals,
and progress in the program. Services provided include individual
(weekly), group (4 times per week), recreational activity (3-4 times
per week), and family (weekly) therapy for Youth A on a consistent
basis. During this period, Youth A received three
psychiatric/medication reviews monthly. His treatment goals are
identified as he will demonstrate a significant decrease in deviant
arousal and eliminate his risk to sexually re-offend, he will adhere
to rules and structure both in placement and in the
community/home, evidence the ability to sue coping skills to
manage his sadness, anger , and anxiety without acting out
behaviorally, demonstrate age appropriate skills in the area of
independent living skills, and evidence the ability to respond in a
manner that evidences a connection with reality. Documentation
9

indicates Youth A continues to struggle in reaching his goals and
continues to require “significant support”.
Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 has no
documented disciplinary action in his HR file. He was hired on
7/8/2002 and completed his last CPI NVCI training on 1/26/2023.
Human Resources file for Staff 2 was reviewed. Staff 2 has no
documented disciplinary action in his HR file. He was hired on
1/20/1999 and completed his last CPI NVCI training on
11/28/2022.
Human Resources file for Supervisor 2 was reviewed.
Supervisor 2 has no documented disciplinary action in her HR file.
She was hired on 11/3/2008 and completed her last CPI NVCI
training on 2/23/2023.
Human Resources file for Supervisor 3 was reviewed.
Supervisor 3 has no documented disciplinary action in her HR file.
She was hired on 1/8/2007 and completed her last CPI NVCI
training on 6/19/2023.
Human Resources file for Nurse Manager was reviewed.
Nurse Manager has no documented disciplinary action in her HR
file. She was hired on 12/11/2017 and completed her last CPI
NVCI training on 9/2023.
Policy 8503109 Proper use and monitoring of physical
restraint and seclusion for the Impulse Disorder Program.
There is no date on this document. This document outlines the
policy for restraints of youth. Restraints are to be conducted only
to protect the youth or others from “imminent risk” and to be used
“only as the last resort”. A restraint is not to last longer than
needed to end the threat of serious physical harm. The types of
restraints are outlined, and only physical restraints taught through
CPI NVCI are to be used and a prone position restraint is strictly
prohibited.
Patient Advocate Investigative Report dated 7/28/23 and
authored by Complainant. This document summarizes the
patient advocates investigation of the restraint of Youth A
occurring on 7/25/23. She was notified the day of the occurrence
by Supervisor 1 and Nurse. Staff 1, Staff 2, Supervisor 2, and
Nurse Manager were identified as participating the restraint and
Supervisor 3 and Clinician witnessing the restraint. Interviews with
Supervisor 1, Nurse, Staff 1, Supervisor 2, Staff 2, Supervisor 3,
10

Nurse Manager, Clinician, Trainer, and Youth A were completed.
Two CPI-NVCI instructors were interviewed, and both reported
instructing their classes to never do a prone restraint and if the
youth gets into the prone position, they are to let go or re-adjust
and re-hold if necessary. This report has a detailed review of the
video surveillance, and it is noted Youth A was observed moving
his extremities 6 times for less than 1 minute each time during the
whole restraint. Differences between the interviews conducted for
this report by licensing and the descriptions of interviews
contained in the Patient Advocate report are as follows.
• Supervisor 1: in a written report she stated Staff 1 informed
Supervisor 1 that he was unable to move Youth A from a
prone position because “he is trying to hurt us”.
• Staff 1: He stated to the Patient Advocate he was told if a
kid is down not to turn him over if he’s secure. He also
stated I was always told it’s better to secure any way we
can because I have to look out for the staff too.
• Supervisor 2: She stated to the Patient Advocate, Youth A
should not be in a prone position and attempts were made
to get him over. She also stated staff were trying to
deescalate him and every time they tried to release him, he
began to struggle.
• Staff 2: He stated to the Patient Advocate, Youth A was
going to stab me, but Youth A was around 5 feet away and
he wanted to let Youth A go but Staff 1 said to secure
Youth A. He also stated, CPI NVCI tells us to secure in
whatever way we can and I’m not sure what our prone
policy says.
• Supervisor 3: She stated to the Patient Advocate, Staff 1
informed Supervisor 1 he could not move Youth A from a
prone position because he was still struggling.
• Clinician: She stated to the Patient Advocate, Youth A was
more squirming than fighting and knew Youth A should not
be down in a prone position, but I was focused on de-
escalating him.
• The conclusion of this report outlines that all staff involved
have completed the updated CPI NVCI training which
includes no use of a prone restraint. At no point did any
staff verbalize the need to let Youth A go or turn him over
with the exception of Supervisor 1 and Staff 2. The majority
of the time during the restraint as evidenced by the video
recording indicates Youth A was not moving his extremities.
It is also noted the trainer and other training staff concluded
there were multiple opportunities for Youth A to be moved
to a safe position or roll to a supine position. The Patient
Advocate concluded Staff 1 caused nonaccidental physical
11

injury to Youth A and child abuse is substantiated. Because
of the length of the restraint and prone position, child
neglect is substantiated.
Compliance Hotline Investigation Report number 2023-7-xxx
dated 7/25/2023. This document identifies Administrator 2 as the
investigator and Supervisor 1 as the complainant. The principal
allegation is staff used an unauthorized hold on Youth A.
Individuals interviewed include Staff 1, Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2,
Supervisor 3, Nurse Manager, Clinician, and Trainer. The
summary of this report indicates the video recording does not
support interviews that multiple attempts were made to turn Youth
A out of the prone position or release the hold. It is documented in
the interviews Staff 1 stated he tried multiple times to turn Youth A
over but wanted to maintain a secure hold on him to keep Youth A
from self-harm and harming staff. Staff 1 also admitted to knowing
prone restraints are not approved but was uncomfortable moving
Youth A. Staff 2 admitting to knowing he needed to move Youth A
to another position but was following the orders given by Staff 1.
Supervisor 2 admitted to overhearing Staff 2 tell Staff 1 they
should turn Youth A, but Staff 1 insisted on maintaining position.
She also heard Youth A say, “I promise I’ll stop”. She stated
understanding prone restraints are prohibited. Supervisor 3 gave
a similar report during her interview. Nurse Manager gave a
similar report with the addition of hearing Staff 1 tell Supervisor
“we can’t turn him over”. Clinician also gave similar report with the
except of stating she was the “baby” of the group and trusted her
co-workers were making the right decision even though she knew
a prone restraint was forbidden. Supervisor 1 gave the same
report as she provided when interviewed. The disposition of this
report is that staff are substantiated for the use of an unauthorized
prone restraint on Youth A.
Residential Crisis Incident Report for Youth A dated 7/25/2023
at 8:08 am. This document outlines the restraint and staff
involved. The description is similar to the report by the individual’s
interviewed. The Chief Administrator signed the document and
indicated the restraint was required due to Youth A posing an
imminent danger to staff.
Seclusion/Restraint order dated 7/25/2023 @ 8:29 am. This
document outlines the type of intervention being a physical
restraint with Haldol 10 mg IM and Benadryl 150 mg IM being
administered. The criterion for release involves no
threats/behavioral directed at harm to self/others. The reason for
the restraint is identified as imminent danger to others and the
12

specific behavior is threatening to stab staff, kicking, punching,
and biting. Nurse Manager is identified as informing the treating
physician about the restraint and need for medication.
Seclusion/Restraint patient debriefing for Youth A dated
7/26/23 @ 9:11. This document outlines Youth A’s perception of
the events leading to the restraint, his description of events
causing his behaviors, his perception of what could have been
done differently, trauma experienced by him, and ways to prevent
future similar incidents. There is documentation of Youth A giving
input into each of these areas and his focus was to be released
from the restraint and be allowed to go across the street to the
main building.
Video recording review dated 7/25/2023. The view is the length
of a hallway in the facility. Youth A is observed trying to kick Staff
1 and Staff 1 grabs Youth A’s leg, pulling him until Youth A falls to
the floor in a prone position. Youth A moves to a kneeling position
but is still in a face down position when Staff 1 immediately
engages in the restraint by placing his right hand on Youth A’s
back and grabbing Youth A’s left arm with his left hand as Youth A
moves to a kneeling position. In a few moments Staff 2 secures
Youth A’s right shoulder and arm and Youth A is flat on the floor in
a prone position. Supervisor 2 engages and secures Youth A’s
legs. Youth A does not appear to be resisting the restraint and
only a couple of times is there observed movement from Youth A
as if he were resisting. Several times, Staff 1 changes position to
a sitting position and appears to relax his grab on Youth A. In
these instances, Staff 1 removes his right hand from Youth A and
Youth A just lays still on the floor. Nurse Manager enters the room
and assists with Youth A’s legs until leaving. Throughout this time
Supervisor 3 is in the room observing and moving around.
Clinician enters the room and walks over to the restraint. She
stands near and appears to be communicating with Youth A.
Clinician leaves. Finally, Supervisor 1 and Nurse 1 enter the room
and walk to the restraint and after a few moments, Staff 1, Staff 2,
and Supervisor 2 all release Youth A. Youth A then leans against
the wall in a sitting position. At no time prior to Supervisor 1
interaction, is there any indication that staff are attempting to
remove Youth A from a prone position. Youth A is observed only
moving a few times and his struggling appears minimal at most.
The overall time for Youth A in the prone position is between 21
and 22 minutes.
13

Analysis Based upon interviews, written documentation and video
surveillance, evidence supports Staff 1, Staff 2, and Supervisor 2
all placed Youth A in a prone position during a restraint. Nurse
Manager, Supervisor 3, and Clinician all were aware of the prone
position restraint but did nothing to intervene in this inappropriate
restraint. All six of these staff members had been up to date on
their restraint training which teaches prone position restraints are
strictly prohibited.
Conclusion Violation Established

Documents Reviewed:
Policy 8503109 Proper use and monitoring of physical
restraint and seclusion for the impulse disorder program.
This document also outlines the requirement of a “face-to-face

condition
• An assessment of the need to continue or terminate the

Within 30-minutes following the medical evaluation, if the

consult with the attending physician or other LIP responsible for

monitor the youths for signs of physical distress. The nurse is to
immediately assign a staff member to conduct continuous in

Analysis Based upon interviews, written documentation and video
surveillance, evidence supports the facility failed to follow their
policies and procedures in the following areas:
• Facility did not follow policy of documenting 5-minute
checks on Youth A during the restraint.
• Facility did not complete the documentation for 15-minutes
checks as required (form was not completed).
• Facility did not complete the physical assessment within 1-
hour after the restraint and the documentation was
incomplete which provided no evidence of the assessment
being completed.
• Facility did not replace medication removed from the
emergency injectable box, causing a delay in Youth A
receiving the injection during the restraint.
